clusters.title: Does my vagina really need a ‘facial’?
clusters.neutral_headline: Vagina wellness products and "vaginal facials" are discussed

items.title: Does my vagina really need a ‘facial’?
items.standfirst: The idea that your vagina should smell as fresh as a daisy or look like a doll’s is an insult to your humanity and a hazard to your healthHi Ugly,I have been noticing a barrage of ads for “vaginal wellness” products: suppositories, balms and serums, and even a “vagi facial” at a local spa. What’s up with this? I was always taught that my vagina was self-cleaning and beautiful. Suddenly I am not so sure, and even find myself wondering if my labia are “normal” or in fact gross. Is this really happening?Why is this column called ‘Ask Ugly’?My father had plastic surgery. Now he wants me and my mother to get work doneHow should I be styling my pubic hair?How do I deal with imperfection?I want to ignore beauty culture. But I’ll never get anywhere if I don’t look a certain way Continue reading...
items.content: The idea that your vagina should smell as fresh as a daisy or look like a doll’s is an insult to your humanity and a hazard to your healthHi Ugly,I have been noticing a barrage of ads for “vaginal wellness” products: suppositories, balms and serums, and even a “vagi facial” at a local spa. What’s up with this? I was always taught that my vagina was self-cleaning and beautiful. Suddenly I am not so sure, and even find myself wondering if my labia are “normal” or in fact gross. Is this really happening?Why is this column called ‘Ask Ugly’?My father had plastic surgery. Now he wants me and my mother to get work doneHow should I be styling my pubic hair?How do I deal with imperfection?I want to ignore beauty culture. But I’ll never get anywhere if I don’t look a certain way Continue reading...

ai_summary: The article questions the need for "vaginal wellness" products.

The author discusses the impact of beauty standards on women.

It raises concerns about the potential health hazards of these products.

items.standfirst: Despite being repeatedly asked, No 10 declines to say the PM was ‘misled’ by MandelsonStephen Doughty, a Foreign Office minister, is responding to the UQ about Peter Mandelson.He starts by making the point that it is the anniversary of the “despicable” 9/11 terrorism attacks.Keir Starmer must sack Peter Mandelson without further delay - and come clean about what he knew when, and whether he sanctioned blocking the publication of damaging material. UK government documents shouldn’t be hidden from the public just because they are damaging to the Labour party - and by backing Peter Mandelson to the hilt, the prime minister’s own reputation is now on the line. Continue reading...

UK government documents shouldn’t be hidden from the public just because they are damaging to the Labour party - and by backing Peter Mandelson to the hilt, the prime minister’s own reputation is now on the line. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Clean air must be made a global priority | Letter
clusters.neutral_headline: Clean air must be made a global priority, says a letter

items.title: Clean air must be made a global priority | Letter
items.standfirst: Left unchecked, toxic air will keep shortening millions of lives and harming health, says Jane BurstonYour article (Millions of Britons face higher risk of heart failure due to dirty air, study suggests, 8 September) is just the latest reminder that toxic air is a public health crisis. The evidence is piling up. There’s also fresh evidence that air pollution can drive devastating forms of dementia.Left unchecked, toxic air will keep shortening lives and worsening health everywhere. But the good news is that solutions are at hand. Academics at Princeton University have recently shown that cutting pollution in the US could save thousands of lives each year. Continue reading...
items.content: Left unchecked, toxic air will keep shortening millions of lives and harming health, says Jane BurstonYour article (Millions of Britons face higher risk of heart failure due to dirty air, study suggests, 8 September) is just the latest reminder that toxic air is a public health crisis. The evidence is piling up. There’s also fresh evidence that air pollution can drive devastating forms of dementia.Left unchecked, toxic air will keep shortening lives and worsening health everywhere. But the good news is that solutions are at hand. Academics at Princeton University have recently shown that cutting pollution in the US could save thousands of lives each year. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The article discusses the impact of toxic air on health.
It highlights the shortening of lives due to air pollution.
The article mentions a study on air pollution and dementia.
Solutions to reduce air pollution are available.
Cutting pollution in the US could save thousands of lives.

clusters.title: Striking tube drivers have proved a point | Brief letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Tube drivers strike highlights importance, letters discuss other topics

items.title: Striking tube drivers have proved a point | Brief letters
items.standfirst: Chaos on London roads | Smiling drivers | Samantha Cameron’s trading woes | Banksy’s gavel | A harsh recoveryAnyone caught in the chaos of the mad, traffic-infested streets in London as they tried to get home during the strike by RMT tube drivers might realise how important those drivers are in keeping London running smoothly (Report, 8 September). Perhaps it’s worth paying them more and reducing their working hours.Dr Alan LaffertyLondon• Regarding the letter on smiling (Letters, 10 September), I am told by my son that no one gives way to another vehicle in the south. While this is possibly a wild generalisation, I find that letting a vehicle into a queue of traffic in front of you changes a stressed face to a smile of thanks.Jeanette HamiltonBuxton, Derbyshire Continue reading...
items.content: Chaos on London roads | Smiling drivers | Samantha Cameron’s trading woes | Banksy’s gavel | A harsh recoveryAnyone caught in the chaos of the mad, traffic-infested streets in London as they tried to get home during the strike by RMT tube drivers might realise how important those drivers are in keeping London running smoothly (Report, 8 September). Perhaps it’s worth paying them more and reducing their working hours.Dr Alan LaffertyLondon• Regarding the letter on smiling (Letters, 10 September), I am told by my son that no one gives way to another vehicle in the south. While this is possibly a wild generalisation, I find that letting a vehicle into a queue of traffic in front of you changes a stressed face to a smile of thanks.Jeanette HamiltonBuxton, Derbyshire Continue reading...

ai_summary: The article discusses the importance of tube drivers.
It suggests paying tube drivers more and reducing hours.

items.standfirst: Jamie Pearson killed himself in toilet at Blackpool Victoria hospital after being admitted over painkiller overdoseThe death of a 27-year-old man who killed himself in a hospital toilet after waiting 22 hours to be seen by the mental health team was “contributed to by neglect”, a coroner has ruled.Jamie Pearson was admitted to Blackpool Victoria hospital’s A&E department after taking an overdose of high-strength painkillers on 17 August 2024. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Michel Odent obituary
clusters.neutral_headline: Michel Odent obituary: Obstetrician revolutionized childbirth

items.title: Michel Odent obituary
items.standfirst: Obstetrician whose work in a French hospital and then in London led to a revolution in how mothers are treated in labourThe pioneering French obstetrician Michel Odent, who has died aged 95, spent more than 50 years passionately promoting understanding of the natural physiology of childbirth. From the 1960s onwards, “active management of labour”, using artificial oxytocin and other techniques, had dominated obstetric practice. Odent’s work flagged up its pitfalls, and offered an alternative view.Daniela Drandić of the International Confederation of Midwives said: “In the 1970s birth was institutionalised and medicalised. Michel Odent reminded us that physiological processes during pregnancy and birth should be respected, which was very important as things had gone too far in the other direction. There wasn’t much discourse at the time and he showed us another way.” Continue reading...
items.content: Obstetrician whose work in a French hospital and then in London led to a revolution in how mothers are treated in labourThe pioneering French obstetrician Michel Odent, who has died aged 95, spent more than 50 years passionately promoting understanding of the natural physiology of childbirth. From the 1960s onwards, “active management of labour”, using artificial oxytocin and other techniques, had dominated obstetric practice. Odent’s work flagged up its pitfalls, and offered an alternative view.Daniela Drandić of the International Confederation of Midwives said: “In the 1970s birth was institutionalised and medicalised. Michel Odent reminded us that physiological processes during pregnancy and birth should be respected, which was very important as things had gone too far in the other direction. There wasn’t much discourse at the time and he showed us another way.” Continue reading...

ai_summary: Michel Odent, a pioneering obstetrician, has died.
He promoted understanding of natural childbirth physiology.
Odent challenged the use of artificial oxytocin.
He offered an alternative view on childbirth practices.
His work influenced the way mothers are treated in labor.

clusters.title: GMC examines doctor’s Reform speech linking vaccines to royal family cancer
clusters.neutral_headline: GMC examines doctor’s Reform speech linking vaccines to royal family cancer

items.title: GMC examines doctor’s Reform speech linking vaccines to royal family cancer
items.standfirst: Medical bodies and prime minister condemn Aseem Malhotra’s ‘pseudo-science’ remarks at party conferenceThe General Medical Council is examining comments by a controversial doctor who used a speech at Reform UK’s conference to link Covid vaccines to cancer in the royal family, amid mounting condemnation of him by senior medics.The regulator, which is charged with upholding professional standards in UK medicine, is also progressing with an investigation into Aseem Malhotra, currently an adviser to Donald Trump’s health secretary, Robert F Kennedy, over a previous claim. It may consider whether to stop or limit his ability to work as a doctor in the UK in the interests of protecting the public. Continue reading...
items.content: Medical bodies and prime minister condemn Aseem Malhotra’s ‘pseudo-science’ remarks at party conferenceThe General Medical Council is examining comments by a controversial doctor who used a speech at Reform UK’s conference to link Covid vaccines to cancer in the royal family, amid mounting condemnation of him by senior medics.The regulator, which is charged with upholding professional standards in UK medicine, is also progressing with an investigation into Aseem Malhotra, currently an adviser to Donald Trump’s health secretary, Robert F Kennedy, over a previous claim. It may consider whether to stop or limit his ability to work as a doctor in the UK in the interests of protecting the public. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The GMC is examining a doctor's comments on vaccines.
The doctor linked Covid vaccines to cancer in the royal family.
Medical bodies condemn the doctor's remarks.
The GMC is investigating the doctor's previous claims.
The regulator may limit his ability to practice medicine.

items.title: ‘The chaos is the point’: tumult as Covid vaccine boosters deployed under RFK Jr
items.standfirst: People attempting to obtain vaccine report major hurdles amid new limitations brought in by Trump health secretaryThe first deployment of updated Covid shots under the Trump administration has been plagued by access issues and misinformation amid confusion and chaos at US health agencies.People attempting to get the vaccines say they have struggled to understand eligibility requirements, book appointments, process insurance claims, battle misinformation from pharmacists and obtain prescriptions from their doctors in some states. Such hurdles will disproportionately affect people of color and low-income people, experts say. Continue reading...

Such hurdles will disproportionately affect people of color and low-income people, experts say. Continue reading...

clusters.title: More than half of UK births now involve medical intervention, audit finds
clusters.neutral_headline: Medical Intervention in Over Half of UK Births

items.title: More than half of UK births now involve medical intervention, audit finds
items.standfirst: Caesareans drive rise in assisted deliveries as experts warn of complex pregnancies linked to age, obesity and other conditionsMore than half of women having a baby in Britain now do so with the help of medical intervention, an audit of NHS maternity care has revealed.Of the 592,594 births that took place in 2023, 50.6% involved either a caesarean section or the use of instruments such as forceps or a ventouse suction cup. Continue reading...
items.content: Caesareans drive rise in assisted deliveries as experts warn of complex pregnancies linked to age, obesity and other conditionsMore than half of women having a baby in Britain now do so with the help of medical intervention, an audit of NHS maternity care has revealed.Of the 592,594 births that took place in 2023, 50.6% involved either a caesarean section or the use of instruments such as forceps or a ventouse suction cup. Continue reading...

ai_summary: An audit revealed over half of UK births in 2023 involved medical intervention.
Caesarean sections are a major factor driving the increase in assisted deliveries.
Experts highlight complex pregnancies linked to age, obesity, and other conditions.
50.6% of 592,594 births in 2023 involved intervention like forceps or ventouse.
The findings come from an audit of NHS maternity care across the United Kingdom.

items.title: US drugmaker Merck scraps £1bn London research centre and cuts 125 science jobs
items.standfirst: New blow to UK’s key life science sector as industry body says country is losing ground on investment and researchThe US drugmaker Merck has scrapped a £1bn London research centre and is laying off 125 scientists in the capital this year, in a big blow to the UK’s important life science sector.Keir Starmer’s government has described life sciences as “one of the crown jewels of the UK economy” and the previous Conservative government had vowed to turn the country into a “global science and technology superpower” by 2030. Continue reading...

Continue reading...
